instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: MacBook Air (Retina, 13-inch, 2020) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. Boot loping after liquid damaged
threads.message:
Hi. I need help, please.
This MacBook had liquid damage around <CAPACITOR>C7661</CAPACITOR>(replaced), <RESISTOR>R5430</RESISTOR>(resolder), <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR>(All cleaned with flux), small oxidation on <CAPACITOR>C6532</CAPACITOR>.
After cleaning all corrosion and resoldering some components I've cleaned with Ultra Sonic cleaning.
Measuring on L9060 it starts on 12.60V then drops to 12.30 for 3 secs and back to 12.60.
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> starts with 12.61V and drops to 12.30V for a few secs and back to 12.61V.
I've replaced even <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> and still the same issue.
Can't boot in internet mode or from an external system it keeps rebooting.
Can someone point me in some direction?
Thanks

threads.title: MacBook Air (Retina, 13-inch, 2020) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. Boot loping after liquid damaged
threads.message:
Any liquid sign on audio card?
Remove it and inspect hidden side; also check audio flex and connectors.

Did you try DFU?

threads.title: MacBook Air (Retina, 13-inch, 2020) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. Boot loping after liquid damaged
threads.message:
Yes, there was liquid on the audio card, I forgot to mention. The audio card had U.S cleaning.
I tried to boot with the audio board disconnected and the same.
DFU mode works and revives option goes all steps fine. But after restarts the same issue.
It keeps restarting after trying to boot.
It's not working on the battery, only with the charger connected.
I've done this video showing the voltage-in.
[MEDIA=youtube]8H4FaqGZy8o[/MEDIA]

threads.title: MacBook Air (Retina, 13-inch, 2020) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. Boot loping after liquid damaged
threads.message:
I bet some T2 data line to audio board was damaged.
Such small audio board receives <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and leakage to data lines is very often.

threads.title: MacBook Air (Retina, 13-inch, 2020) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. Boot loping after liquid damaged
threads.message:
Ok, I see.
So, In other words, it will work again just if replace the T2 chip?

threads.title: MacBook Air (Retina, 13-inch, 2020) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. Boot loping after liquid damaged
threads.message:
We didn't get any positive feedback about changing T2 on the forum.
Did you try DFU restore?
This will erase SSD.
If data is important, check first if can get access to it in Target Disk mode and save data.

threads.title: MacBook Air (Retina, 13-inch, 2020) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. Boot loping after liquid damaged
threads.message:
I've tried only revive. 
I will save the data in target disk and do a restore.
